bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. BURGESS:H.R. 5950.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:The attached language falls within Congress' delegatedauthority to legislate interstate commerce, found in ArticleI, Section 8, clause 3 of the U.S. Constitution. Further,Congress' authority to authorize the FAA to regulate airspacewithin the U.S. has been found to be within its authorityunder the General Welfare clause of the U.S. Constitution,Article I, Section 8, clause 1.[Page H3707]

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Aviation.
Referred to the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure.

summary.text: No Armed Drones Act of 2012 or NADA Act of 2012 - Amends the FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 to prohibit the Secretary of Transportation (DOT) from authorizing any person to: (1) operate an unmanned aircraft system (drone) in the national airspace system as a weapon or to deliver a weapon against a person or property; or (2) manufacture, sell, or distribute a drone (or a component of one) for such a use.

bill.title: NADA Act of 2012

item.title: To amend the FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 to establish prohibitions to prevent the use of unmanned aircraft systems as weapons while operating in the national airspace system, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Aviation.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
